High Detectability.name: Unused Element / Empty Diagram
High Detectability.heuristic: Model element has no incoming or outgoing references. Unused class, attribute, association, or empty diagram.

High Detectability.name: Redundancy / Model Clones
High Detectability.heuristic: Two or more elements or diagrams are identical or nearly identical in structure, attributes, or relationships.

High Detectability.name: Over-Decomposition / Mixed Detail Levels
High Detectability.heuristic: Model mixes multiple abstraction or decomposition levels (e.g., system-level + design-level classes).

High Detectability.name: Non-Expressive Name
High Detectability.heuristic: Name does not describe its nature (e.g., 'Class1', 'Temp', 'DataObj').

High Detectability.name: Too Short or Generic Diagram Name
High Detectability.heuristic: Diagram name is generic or minimal, like 'Model1' or 'MainDiagram'.

High Detectability.name: Poorly Written Text
High Detectability.heuristic: Comments or documentation fields have poor grammar, unclear terms, or are excessively long.

High Detectability.name: Inconsistent Representation
High Detectability.heuristic: Same concepts modeled in different ways (e.g., inconsistent attribute names or stereotypes).

High Detectability.name: High Coupling
High Detectability.heuristic: Element depends on too many others; large number of associations or cross-package dependencies.

High Detectability.name: No Clear Focus / Overloaded Element
High Detectability.heuristic: Diagram or element mixes unrelated concepts or has multiple unrelated responsibilities.

Moderate Detectability.name: Information in Unexpected Place
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Text or metadata appears in comments or wrong diagram, not in model metadata fields.

Moderate Detectability.name: Too Few Details
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Model or process is too abstract — missing internal actions, states, or relationships.

Moderate Detectability.name: Imprecise Model
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Missing key relationships or constraints, ambiguous attributes, or vague actor definitions.

Moderate Detectability.name: Hidden Dependencies
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Logical dependencies exist that are not explicitly linked in the model.

Moderate Detectability.name: Mixed Abstraction Levels
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Model mixes conceptual, logical, and physical layers together.

Moderate Detectability.name: Modeler Doesn’t Understand Process
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Incomplete or illogical sequence of actions; missing decision points.

Moderate Detectability.name: Expired Model Element
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Element describes obsolete or outdated concepts no longer relevant to the system.

Moderate Detectability.name: Too Big Diagram
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Diagram has too many elements or connections, overloaded even structurally in XMI.

Moderate Detectability.name: Not Following Modeling Style
Moderate Detectability.heuristic: Non-standard stereotypes, inconsistent association directionality, irregular UML element use.

Low Detectability.name: Model Testing Takes Too Long
Low Detectability.heuristic: Model or test diagrams are excessively complex or unscalable.

Low Detectability.name: Incomplete Model Testing
Low Detectability.heuristic: Missing coverage for some modeled elements or processes.

Low Detectability.name: Testing Tracking / Borderline Issues Ignored
Low Detectability.heuristic: Missing test linkage or weak traceability among model elements.

Low Detectability.name: Not Remembering History
Low Detectability.heuristic: No model version metadata or versioning evidence.

Low Detectability.name: Metadata in Wrong Place
Low Detectability.heuristic: Author/time/version stored as comments instead of metadata.
